user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of alloc:
```c
static int alloc(void)
{
	void *ptr;

	ptr = metal_allocate_memory(1000);
	if (!ptr) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_DEBUG, "failed to allocate memory\n");
		return errno;
	}

	metal_free_memory(ptr);

	return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function alloc:
#define metal_log(level, fmt, __VA_ARGS__) ({if(_metal.common.log_handler&&level<=_metal.common.log_level)_metal.common.log_handler(level,metal_fmt(fmt),##__VA_ARGS__);\
})
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
metal_log(METAL_LOG_DEBUG, "failed to allocate memory\n");
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The code fragment only passes a string literal to the metal_log macro; neither the macro expansion shown nor this call uses any of the <string.h> functions listed in MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17. Therefore, based on the fragment alone there is no evidence of out‑of‑bounds accesses caused by memcpy/memmove/memset/memcmp/strcpy/strncpy/strcat/strncat/strlen/strspn. (Note: if metal_fmt or _metal.common.log_handler internally use unsafe string.h calls with incorrect buffer sizes, those implementations — not this call site — could violate Rule 21.17.)
